This ethical and political purpose, however insufficient to explain the treatise as a whole, has powerfully influenced the treatment of considerable portions³. In exhibiting to his readers the great free people who alone among thenations had ever cast off the yoke once laid upon· them, and caused a distinct recession of the Roman frontier, he would naturally use all his skill to idealize the vigorous and manly qualities standing in the sharpest contrast to the enfeebling luxury and vicious degradation of Roman contemporary lis.
